summary.p: Pars I. Poema Aethiopicum seu Encomium sanctorum coelestium et terrestrium pertotum annum Auctore Anonymo. Pars II. Varia carmina Aethiopica variorum auctorum de variis rebus collecta a Jobo Ludolpho (fol. ).
I) ውዳሴ᎓ ሰማያውያን᎓ ወምድራውያን “Praise of the Celestial and Earthly Ones” (fols. )
II) Viri illustris Hiobi Ludolfii de hujus libri authore, Conjectura “Conjecture of the Famous Doctor H. Ludolf ” (fol. ), in Latin
III) Seguuntur Poemata varia miscellanea…, Miscellaneous poems (fols. )
III-) Qǝne-hymn of the type ˁǝtanä mogär (fol. ), praising the Ethiopian King Susǝnyos (r. )
III-) ˁƎtanä mogär-poem in Amharic composed by ˀabba Gorgoryos (fol. )
III-) Encomium patriarcharum, Abrahami, Isaaci et Jacobi, per omnia membra corporis laudatorum, Mälkǝˀ-hymn for Abraham, Isaac and Jacob (fols. ), probably incomplete, stanzas
III-) Mälkǝˀ-hymn for St. Michael (fols. ), incomplete, stanzas
III-) Mälkǝˀ-hymn for St. Mary (fols. ), incomplete, stanzas
III-) Mälkǝˀ-hymn to Samuel “the Miracle Worker” (Thaumaturgus) of Fätale” (fols. ), stanzas
III-) Śǝllase-hymn to Samuel “the Miracle Worker” (fol. ), stanzas

III-) Qǝne-poems on the types ˁǝṭanä mogär, mäwäddǝs, śǝllase composed by ˀabba Gorgoryos in honour of Hiob Ludolf (fols. ); a Latin note on fol. indicates that one of them was composed by Gorgoryos on December
III-) “Canticle” and other hymns composed by ˀabba Gorgoryos for “ras Yoḥannǝs ˀErnäst” (Ernst I, Duke of Saxen-Gotha-Altenburg) (fols. )
III-) Epitaphs composed by Hiob Ludolf in memory of individuals: Gabriel Reussel, Samuel Morland, Laurentius Odhelius, Joh. Henr. Haenerus (fol. )
IV) Note on the Ethiopian calendar extended by H. Ludolf with a list of the Coptic and Arabic month names (fol. )

layout.ab: The ruling is executed probably with plummet and consists of only two ruled lines demarcating the written area: the uppermost horizontal line and the innermost vertical line.

handDesc.handNote:
17th-century European hand, fine and careful.
The scribe was a learned person who mastered Ethiopic, Greek and Arabic. His signature on fols. and seems to be composed of three letters, “JHW”, deciphered in this way already by A. Dillmann (see Mehren :), but without any identification proposal. If the reading “JHW” is correct, the name of the scribe might have been Johann Hermann Weissenbruch. He belonged to the circle of Hiob Ludolf () and was in close contact with the latter around the time referred to in the manuscript (I am grateful for the hint to Mrs Eugenia Sokolinski for the hint).
None
None

decoNote.p: - Monthly divisions of Text I are indicated by the names of the months (in Latin and Ethiopic) in the top margin of the folios.
- Old pagination in European hand, in Arabic numerals.
European codex. Spine and corners made of parchment. Covers marbled in yellow, blue, red and white, slightly faded.

origin.origDate: Copying date: A note on fol. 75v (bottom margin, left side), after Text I, reads, “Contuli cum protographo Wanslebiano m. Februar. A.d. 1695 [signature]”. Another note, on the right side, reads, “Absolvi. d. ix Sept. 92. [Signature] Francof. ad Moenum”. Therefore, the writing of Text I was completed on 9 September 1692, the collation of the text with the exemplar manuscript of Wansleben was finished in February 1695. The colophon on fol. 87r reads, “Absolvi xxviii. Febr. A. clᴐlᴐcxcv. [Signature]”; the indicated date 28 February 1695 is the time when the writing of the last text was completed.
